text: when I read malala's Diaries for the
first time it was quite obvious that she
had something to say language was very
simple which made her narrative even
more powerful and of course at that time
she was only 12 years old so she had the
innocence of a child but still she was
very very passionate and committed to
education and it was amazing the way she
talked about her own fears and those of
her friends I had a terrible dream
yesterday with military helicopters and
the Taliban I have had such dreams since
the launch of the military operation in
Sabbath my mother made me breakfast and
I went off to school I was afraid going
to school because the Taliban had issued
an edict banning all girls from
attending schools on my way from school
to home I heard a man saying I will kill
you I hastened my pace and after a while
I looked back if the man was still
coming behind me but to my utter relief
he was talking on his mobile and must
have been threatening someone else over
the phone of course we get malala's an
identity secret in order to protect her
because everything that we put up on the
BBC YouTube page is often immediately
picked up by the local media and there
was a particular interest in her Diaries
because she was the only voice coming
out of Swat and there was no other way
for finding out what was going on in the
valley
then once the government had pushed
alabang out the Swat malala's family
decided to go public with her identity
and from there on she campaigned
publicly for education and she was quite
a well-known figure inside the country
by the time she was at that
I still remember that day when I walked
into the section the news had come in by
that time and everybody was very quiet I
could see the sense of shock it was
almost a kind of a sense of despair that
that that I saw in the office and that
was actually a history-making moment
because that was the time when she
became known all over the world well I
think as a person she's an exceptionally
brave person but she's not just a person
she is a symbol she's a symbol of hope
for tens of millions of girls in
Pakistan who are as committed to
education as Malala is but they they
fear for their future because of a lack
of opportunity at times because of the
inherent conservatism of the Pakistani
society
it's these millions of girls that Malala
represents and which is why it's such a
proud day for Pakistan where all those
girls that are not known to the world
and that their number runs into millions
they look at her they listen to her and
in her they find the hope
